To be honest, this novel needs no detailed review. You just need to know two facts: 
1. I strongly believe that "Umineko no naku koro ni" is one of the best stories I've read in my life, and I've read quite a lot.
2. By choosing not to read "Umineko" you miss the most interesting, challenging, dramatical and fantastic mystery novel, filled with characters you'll fall in love with, romantic stories that will make you cry, murder cases that will really test your detective skills and amazing music that you will never forget.

38755372.review: Going through the Question Arcs and the Answer Arcs was a life changing experience for me. It made me get into mystery novels and it changed the way I think about truth and belief in general. Reading through the whole story is an emotional roller coaster, I ended up getting more invested in the story of each of the characters that what I thought at first without really realizing it. Some of the music is simply amazing, the sound effects on the other end sound quite silly, but you grow attached to some of them. This story seemlessly go though many genres (mystery, romance, fantasy and horror) without feeling weak on any front. It offers a few interesting thought challenges later on when the riddles become increasingly more difficult to solve. There is a great cast of characters all of which are well written and interesting. One of the think I like the most about it is the hype management. The opposition and threats felt by the main character are very real and the struggle is really hard which makes it all the more satisfying when a come back occurs except maybe in the beginning in the second and third episodes where the main character appear to be incompetent, which is part of is journey and is growth. I definitely recommend.

Welcome to the world of "Umineko When They Cry" (When Seagulls Cry)

Welcome to the Rokkenjima of October 4, 1986.

You have been given a chance to catch a glimpse of the family conference held annually by the Ushiromiya family.

The remaining life in the old family head
who has built up a vast fortune is very slim.

To his children, the greatest point of contention at this family conference
is the distribution of his inheritance. 
Everyone desires all that money, no one relents, and no one believes.

Who will gain the old head's vast inheritance?

Where is the 10 tons of gold that the old head is said to have hidden?

Can the unnerving riddle of the epitaph which is said to point to
the location of that gold be solved?

In the midst of this, a suspicious letter is sent from one claiming to be a witch.

The presence of a 19th person on this island,
which should only have 18, begins to hang in the air.

Brutal murders repeat, and unsolvable riddles are left at the scene.

How many will die? How many will live? Or will everyone die?

Is the culprit one of the 18, or not?

Is the culprit a "human", or a "witch"?

Please, enjoy this isolated island, western mansion,
mystery-suspense gadget of the good old days to the fullest

38382307.review:
Umineko is one of my favorite stories of all time, and I'm so proud to see Witch Hunt finally get all of their hard work published. I started playing with the original patch years ago, back before the PS3 sprites patch was available, and it's definitely the same experience. Thank you so much to Witch Hunt and Ryukishi07 for years of patience and pushing to get the Umineko games an official release for your English speaking fans.

Umineko is a VN in the truest sense -- you don't have any control over the story, you're just watching it all play out. But the storytelling is phenomenal, giving you just enough hints to make your own theories without giving everything away. And the use of sound is absolutely masterful. The sound effects are really great at evoking just the right amount of creepy, and the gore isn't explicit but the sounds that accompany it will still make you cringe. And the music is some of the best video game music out there.

If you're a fan of Higurashi, one of the original bar-setters for the horror VN genre, Umineko definitely keeps up the horror levels and the theme of blurring the lines between reality and illusion, but the romantic undertones really push it over into Favorite VN Of All Time territory for me.

If you're a fan of other horror VN series like Zero Escape and Danganronpa, definitely check out one of if not the greatest precursor in the genre.

Basically, if you're looking for a really fantastic horror mystery visual novel, Umineko is one of the best.

38306927.review:
If you like visual novels and/or the mystery genre, then buy this game. I can't say anything beyond that it is utterly fantastic. The mystery is great, the characters are some of the best I have seen in a game (certainly the best I've seen in a visual novel), and a great part of the storytelling itself is wonderfully unique, original and engaging. I don't think it is a thoroughly perfect visual novel, but none of the games I think are 10/10s are.

If there is something specific I can say about this game, it is its use of meta-storytelling. I have played and seen a lot of games that employ this, like Undertale's save and load mechanics, the entirety of pony island, the recently popular Doki Doki Literature Club, and not to mention the sleuth of 4th wall breaking characters, lines and plot threads in a lot of contemporary media. I mention all of this because none of what I have seen of meta-storytelling has, I feel, actually added anything of substance to the story that it is present in, it has merely been an interesting and sometimes clever gimmick which can be fun for the audience (me included). Umineko, a game around 10 years old actually did something with its meta-storytelling. It actually made me reflect on how I as the reader relate to and interact with the mystery genre. This was by no means something only I experienced by chance, the writer of Umineko, Ryukishi07, obviously intended for his game to have this effect on the reader.

Of course, this is just one theme in this long visual novel, however the fact remains that, in my limited experience at least, it is the only game I've played to use meta-narrative in such a meaningful way to evoke thoughts from me that only meta-narrative specifically could with such effectiveness.

I just remembered that The Beginners Guide and [spoiler] Danganronpa V3 [/spoiler] also used their meta-narrative in a meaningful way, but my point still stands, only with less force. Far less force. However in those games the meta-narrative only became meaningful to the story near the end, while in Umineko it is a pervasive theme throughout and integral to the game's very nature. What I'm saying is that Umineko actually managed to change my attitude towards the mystery genre, and any game that can actually change my views and/or attitudes is pretty sweet in my books.

Wow that was a long-winded way to say a simple thing.

TL;DR You like VN's? Like mystery? Get Umineko, grab a pen and some paper, solve the mystery yourself, and never find out whether you were entirely right or not. 10.8/10 not enough seagulls.

I'm 27 hours in and I still don't understand what the goals of the story or the characters are. I was surprised how slowly the mystery part is developing and being revealed, instead the story likes to lean more heavily on character development: I estimate that I've spent 60-70% of the time following character interactions or learning about their backgrounds (first 3 episodes I played). So far we have about 22 characters in the cast, and at this rate I fear that by the end of the show we have learned the detailed past, present and future for all of them.
That aspect is executed greatly, don't get me wrong, but it didn't end up being my cup of tea because I prefer having the mystery being the core of the show surrounded by a set of interesting characters, not the other way around.

I can't deny that the quality of writing or world building wouldn't be excellent and how the story is heading to some epic destination, but I couldn't enjoy the ride because my expectations were so different. The pacing was way too slow and it didn't focus on the aspects I found interesting.

37754603.review:
[strike]totally not written because of the steam awards[/strike]

From the author of one of my favourite VNs [i]Higurashi no Naku Koro ni[/i], 07th Expansion presents its spiritual successor: [b]Umineko no Naku Koro ni[/b], or [i]When the Seagulls Cry[/i]. (You don't actually need to read Higu first tho; they're completely different)

First things first, Umineko is a kinetic visual novel with no choices to be made, so let's be real here: it's more of a lot more of an e-book with sound and graphics than it is a "game." 

The "question arcs" package featured here is only the first half of the story (episodes 1-4) and focuses on establishing the mysteries, world, and providing hints; it took me about 50~ hours to complete. The story is concluded and "answered" through Umineko Chiru (episodes 5-8), also referred to as the "answer arcs" (recently released on Steam). 

Umineko has a great soundtrack, and the crimes and mysteries aren't straightforward even if you know who the culprit is. It's extremely well thought out; there's always hints and foreshadowing that you might not even notice until it's pointed out later. The characters are also very colourful and varied, and I didn't really find myself disliking any by the end.

Umineko admittedly starts off slow; as the start of the first episode focuses on introducing the world, it's honestly kind of bland up until the debut of one of my favourite OST tracks, [url=https://youtu.be/raxEmANPTVc]Golden Slaughterer[/url]. This is also a problem with most question arcs (each episode was originally released seperately), but once you get into the later arcs you're expected to know how things go so these intros become shorter and less necessary. However, once you get past these intros the novel [i]really[/i] picks up. 

If you have the time, please give Umineko a read if you can as it's definitely worth it!!

36818947.review:
Одна из тех историй, что надолго остаются в памяти.
Игра, по которой сделали и мангу, и аниме. Или же сперва была новелла?
Впрочем, Umineko - и первая и вторая ее части - определенно заставляет задуматься, но не над прохождением - а о том, что... И каждый в этой истории сам найдет мысли, на которые его натолкнет эта история.
Ведь, пройдя историю до конца, ее нельзя описать вот так в лоб. Слой за слоем, с каждым шагом она идет глубже и шире, поэтому описание завязки - "Семья Уширомия собирается на семейном острове на ежегодную встречу, не догадываясь, что за ужасы их ждут" - это именно завязка, которая присутствует в истории, но не больше. Завязка, 
 которая очень скоро отходит на второй план, уступая место чему-то большему, сюжету куда увлекательнее. И куда трагичнее.

Где-то когда-то я слышала, что один из основных признаков искусства - оставлять после себя мысли, неоднозначные, может быть даже без четкого конкретного ответа, над которыми можно подумать на досуге.
И в моем личном топе подобных объектов искусства Umineko стоит на одной из первых строчек.
Игрой, новеллой, аниме, мангой - я рада, что эта история существует и советую познакомиться с ней в любом виде.

36653987.review:
Umineko is honestly such a good mystery novel. The nature of the mysteries are so unique. (SPOILERS IF YOU DON'T WANT TO KNOW THE MAIN PLOT) This review is meant for people who have watched or read higurashi.

What is so unique about these mysteries is that sometimes (more times to the later chapters) you see how the event clearly played out, but even when you do, there is still a mystery. The event you see is what happens with magic, but the mystery has to explain the scene with human logic. Battler, the main protaganist, is trying to escape a loop similiar to higurashi's. But there are a few different perameters for it. The most important one is that, unlike higurashi with Rika, Battler 'doesn't remember his memories' from loop to loop. Instead, he is given a connected alternate existence while the events happen. In order to defeat the which, he has to proove that whiches aren't real by going through the mysteries with human logic.
Unlike games like danganronpa where you have a lot of evidence and scheduled time to find it, in umineko, there is barely any evidence. So Battler really has to twist logic and reason into his evidence, while Beetrice narrows down his reasoning with the absolute truth. So unlike murder mysteries, in umineko, Battler's goal isn't really to find the culprit, but to find out how the murder was even possible in the first place.
Umineko has the best story I have ever seen in my life. The characters are very fleshed out, and you can really feel their pain. Umineko has the best romance and one of the only couples that are realistic. I didn't like Higurashi's romance, and I didn't like clannad's romance either. But in Umineko, you can really see the picture and you can really understand it. I've cried so many times for the romance in this.
Umineko also has so many logical twists too. *AHEM CHAPTER 3*. And it is just so logical yet it does such a good job of letting the readers understand. Umineko has easy vocabulary so you don't have to worry about stupid words that you can't even understand. I love Umineko, it presents it's plot in an easy to understand way, but it is also very complex at the same time. It's so much better than reading a book that just had a simple plot but bogus vocabulary that gets in your way of understanding what's happening. 
Umineko is one of those stories that you can't judge on first impressions, and it always can find a way to surprise you, but there are no times where it tries to surprise you just for the sake of it. It surprises you while still making sense with the story.
There are no edgy characters too. And the characters that get spotlights are great. It's pretty hard for me to choose a favorite because they are all great. You can't really determain the character on first impressions, some characters are actually very different than how they act on the outside, and you're predictions will problably be wrong most of the time with them.

The one problem I have with this game, is that the first character that gets a spotlight never gets a spotlight again. And that was pretty annoying for me. Most likely that character will probably get a spotlight again in chiru. 

10/10 You might hate it if you don't like it, but for those who like it, it is the best thing.

36476618.review: Umineko is not for everyone. For me it is the best story I read in my whole life but for someone the twist at the EP 5 can be really annoying. Umineko is not a pure mystery. It's real genre is much more different and for me much more satisfying. If you can accept it for what it is and try to understand it, it will reward you by giving you a really important life lesson. I still believe that Ryukishi07 is a really good guy who tries to show people something rather than writing a "heartless" mystery. Umineko will not going to give you all answers. But you can still find them all by just thinking about it. If you can't find some pieces, there is a manga which gives every answer and even shows new things. If you want to read a life changing story with some mystery sauce, buy it and play it. The first EP starts a little bit slow but when you finish it you will understand that even those slow scanes were actually very important and not just some fillers to make the story longer. If you going to read it finish it before talking about it. Just because you didn't liked the first 4 episodes doesn't mean that you will not like the latter ones. Just give it a chance and finish it and then rewiew it. Also don't forget to download the PS3 patch for better character sprites and backgrounds and one of the best voice acting in a VN.

36197550.review:
Umineko is a sound novel. It's a book with music and atmospheric sound effects and, if you install a patch, voice acting that is frankly incredible. And it never had any questionable content to remove. It's not one of those thirsty games where the patch makes anyone's clothes fall off. It's a beautiful story that takes 60 dang hours to get through. Your interaction with the novel is turning the page and nothing more.

The plot is a love song to mystery novels. The soundtrack is at times haunting, puckish, teasing, triumphant. You feel so much of the plot through the choice of accompaniment. 

To say any more would rob you of some of the experience of trying to define what, even, Umineko is. And my personal definition changed multiple times while reading. 

When steam opened the anime pandora's box and let all the thirsty demons out into the world, this is the hope that was left over. This is the one anime game on steam worth a dang.

36153581.review:
This game is hot garbage. I do mean that. There is zero player interaction, this may as well just be a picture book. It isn't a game by any definition. But if you're into that: cool. It still sucks. The game features an interesting cast of characters with many complex relationships. But they don't matter. You might care at first. The game made me care for the first 12 hours or so. I wanted to know where the story was going. 36 hours in, and it hasn't gone anywhere. The game just keeps looping the same events, making them slightly more disturbing each time around. I really can't explain the full depths of the problems of this game without spoiling it, but since my main goal here is to stop you from playing it by any means I will go ahead and not even bother hiding spoilers. This is your warning. If you are really really really dumb and want to play this really really awful game, stop reading this review.

Everything from here on is dedicated to helping you make peace with your incredibly intelligent choice to turn your nose up at this game and never touch it. So it starts with a premise of a fairly straight forward family gathering, it seems like it is going to be a murder mystery over dear old grandpa's inheritance. A bit cliche but whatever. I wanted to give it a chance. A cliche plot can still be well executed. This game is anything but well executed. You're just stuck in this same two-ish day loop watching the same people die over and over and over and over again. They just kept dying and by the time that half the cast had died for the third time you don't even care about them dying anymore. Also the plot goes from believable period mystery to bizzarre magic supernatural plot in the blink of an eye. It is nonsense. You're told to resist this witch, to not believe in her no matter what, despite having magic done right in front of your face. Despite the fact that's she summoning demons and dragging you through pocket dimensions, and teleporting and who knows what else. The sound track doesn't exist. I don't know why the game has it labeled as having a good one, the majority of the game is silent which just makes you aware of how much time you're waisting. The only sound effects is this one really really gross noise they play when gory stuff happens. Also: there's just random descriptions of really gory things for the sake of gory things. Just because. It got disgusting by the end. 

It is terrible. It is slow. Death is meaningless. Life is meaningless. It is all meaningless and stupid in the world of Umineko. Screw this game and everything about it. The game does one thing right: accurately depicts what it is like to be held captive and tortured by an annoying pretentious old woman. Who you're told doesn't exist. 

I hate this game as I hate hell, all Montagues, and whoever gave it such misleading good reviews in the first place. 

The buyer's remorse is so strong I haven't bought a VN since for fear of it being like Umineko.

36081508.review:
Glad I got into this finally. The fame this game has received is not misplaced. The overall premise of the game is you are shown a murder mystery involving people stuck on an island, and it is narrated to you in what appears to be complete fantasy. Don't make the same mistake I did and rush through the game thinking this is a fantasy game though. Everything is solvable without the absurd theories that are presented to you throughout the game. If you want to take part in trying to solve the mysteries given as you read through, I recommend looking through Knox's commandments on detective fiction so that you have a real shot at thinking about the murders. Note that the visual novel does not actually ever give you the explicit answers to many of the murders, instead choosing to give increasingly obvious hints to the answers as you progress through the chapters, and you'll have to go through wikis and forums for the "answer key."

There's a lot here besides just mystery fiction though. This game has some great world building and a ridiculously good soundtrack. The characters all have believable backstories and motivations for their actions, and some of them are so smart and deceptive that you'll be thrown for a loop at least a few times throughout the read. Admittedly, the first chapter was somewhat dull on the first read, since the setting and characters feel very generic. If you keep reading though, you'll be as addicted as me and ruin your life for a few weeks by the ridiculous story that this game has to offer. You don't have to be a mystery fan to enjoy this experience. Umineko spans many different genres.

Definitely install the PS3 version art patch and voice patch as well. The new art is not nearly as good as the PS3 art.

35632938.review:
I enjoyed the first arc. I'm a mystery fan, and the story is set up to be a perfect mystery: a cast of interesting, mostly-likable characters with extensive interpersonal drama and interesting reasons to hate each other, all trapped on an island when bodies start dropping. It's set 99 years after the first Sherlock Holmes mystery, and the author has a keen appreciation for mystery tropes. Like a lot of the classic mysteries, there's a tension between natural and supernatural explanations, but clearly the natural will - inevitably, as per the genre - win out.

Nope! No explanations, no natural solution. The second arc happens, instaed, and the genre changes completely. Now it's supernatural horror with a deliberately meta edge. Now the plot consists of the likable characters being tortured forever by a vicious and omnipotent witch, a GM with limitless powers whose goal is 'make the cast suffer before they die', and the possibility of a happy ending is absurd as that of a solution inside the mystery genre.

I like dark stories - up to a point. This point: when all hope is extinguished. When the second arc got into full swing, I stopped caring what happened to anyone. Sure, there's some variation in what could happen - how they're doomed - but they're all doomed. The only question is how, and given villainous omnipotence, I don't care about how.

It's absolutely a "love it or hate it" game. Most people love it. I don't. I really don't. The themes that interested me were a decoy, limited to the first arc; the characters the story is "actually about" are the hero, Battler, who I found to be the least interesting of the original major characters, and the villain, Beatrice, who I can't stand.

In the end, I said the eight deadly words - "I don't care what happens to these people" - and uninstalled the game.

To be fair, you have to have a very high IQ to understand Umineko. The magic is extremely subtle, and without a solid grasp of formal logic most of the mysteries will go over a typical reader's head. There's also Beatrice's self-punishing outlook, which is deftly woven into her characterisation- her personal philosophy draws heavily from Dostoevsky literature, for instance. The fans understand this stuff; they have the intellectual capacity to truly appreciate the depths of these mysteries, to realise that they're not just tricks- they say something deep about LIFE. As a consequence people who dislike Umineko truly ARE idiots- of course they wouldn't appreciate, for instance, the tragedy in Battler's existential catchphrase "It's useless, it's all useless" which itself is a cryptic reference to Goncharov's Russian epic Oblomov. I'm smirking right now just imagining one of those addlepated simpletons scratching their heads in confusion as Ryukishi's genius wit unfolds itself on their monitors. What fools.. how I pity them. 

And yes, by the way, i DO have a right to bear One-Winged Crest. And no, you cannot see it. It's for the ladies' eyes only- and even then they have to demonstrate that they're within 5 IQ points of my own (preferably lower) beforehand.

34948208.review:
I prefer my stories to be more on the realistic side rather than fantasy when it comes to mysteries. The plot was a perfect set-up for murder mysteries so when I heard Umineko involves a lot of witches and magic I wasn't sure if I'm gonna like it, in a sense it was like how Battler was trying to deny the witch using human logic. I was so sure that putting magical elements in the story would just complicate and mess up the setting, and it did but surprisingly not in a bad way. Infact Umineko's story thrives on these themes. 

This is what makes Umineko great! by adding these elements it forces you to keep thinking ("Turn the chessboard around") to understand it further. It never felt repetitive even if the events themselves keeps repeating, and its all thanks to the addition of magic. never have I thought that magic would really add to the mystery side of the story, to help you better understand what I mean I'll give you a minor background [strike]spoiler[/strike] of the story.

It starts of with a annual family conference about the inheritance of the familiy's wealth on an isolated island called rokkenjima, when a typhoon passes through isolating the island. The basic premise of the story is  [spoiler] a battle between Battler a resident of the island and BEATRIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIICHE the rumored golden witch who supposedly gave the head of the family 10 tons of gold which became the foundation of the familiys wealth, and in the center of it all an epitapth containing the location the hidden gold promising to give both gold and headship to the person who solves the riddle. The battle of Inheritance turns into a massacre said to be a ritual to ressurect the witch. The tragedy would then sparked a game with both trying to explain how the massacre occured, with no one truly understanding what really happened to the island it created the illusion of the massacres being done by a witch. where magic and reality can simultaneously exist until the truth is revealed. the fight continues with Battler using [strike]twisted[/strike] Human logic to explain that the mysteries can be done by humans while Beatrice explaining the existences of witches and magic as the culprit. Putting them into an Endless battle to understand their own existence and to reveal what really happend in the island.[/spoiler]

From there an epic story about mystery and fantasy is set. Honestly the story is so crazy and confusing that it makes it look like it doesn't make sense, yet the way Umineko explains it makes it sensible, Kinda like a paradox. The writing is really brilliant from references to its underlying themes and use of logical concepts such as Devils proof, Hempels raven and Schrodingers cat, the game perfectly encorporated them to further enhance the story. The soundtrack on the other hand is outstanding it really adds to the experience from the cheerful organ pieces that plays on tense situations to its haunting orchestrals and calm piano pieces, its such a pleasure listening to. I can go on about the things I love about this game but I'll stop it at that. 

[h1]Truly this game is an ENDLESS! masterpiece![/h1] if I can say it in red but I'll settle it with blue since this is my own opinion.

34245583.review:
I'll make it "short", you are probably here, because...
[list]
[*][b]A[/b] You've seen the anime and wonder, whether this is better
[*][b]B[/b] Your weird friend keeps recommending this to you
[/list]
If you don't like the medium "visual novel" itself, then this is probably nothing for you, but the fact that you are reading this tells me that there is at least a slight chance of you buying it. Maybe you didn't even read a visual novel before.
And then there are those, who only read these reviews after they finished the game and already know how good it is.
You can go now.

[u]Info:[/u]
[list]
[*]This game contains episodes 1-4 out of 8
[*]This is a visual novel, so prepare to read (a lot)
[*]There are no choices in here, so it's a strictly linear story
[*]The music is awesome
[/list]

[u]"The game looks awful"[/u]
If you want to try it out, but you don't like the visual quality then I have good news for you, there is a mod for Umineko, that replaces the blurry background photos and the character sprites with the more appealing PS3 art and CGs and even adds voice acting, if you so desire.

[u]"What is it about?"[/u]
Ok, if you don't know anything about Umineko, I won't spoil it for you, but it's a character driven murder mystery with a lot of twists and it's one of the weirdest things you'll ever read, if you decide to do so. The setting may first appear familiar, even after reading the first episode, but when you get to the meat of it, you'll understand how very unique this whole thing is. The writing of Ryukishi07 improved compared to his previous works and can range from super whacky screaming to intelligent conversation.

[u]"So, is it better than the anime?"[/u]
The story is very long and very densely written. There are people who might find that off-putting, on the other hand you get to know the characters a lot better and might find different sides about them. Also, you get the whole story with all the clues to the core mysteries, because nothing was cut out. So, if you care for the story, the characters, their thoughts, the world and the mysteries (which honestly you should), then yes, this is better than the anime.

[u]"I know about Higurashi, how are they related?"[/u]
[b]Short answer:[/b] They are about as connected as the Command & Conquer Tiberium universe and the Red Alert universe.
[b]Long answer:[/b] The setting, characters (most of them), the story etc. are unrelated to each other. Umineko tends to reference Higurashi here and there, but it's in no way important to understand the plot. The way the chaperts are seperated from each other is similar to the way Higurashi did it.

[u]"Even though you love it, are there things you don't like about it?"[/u]
There are indeed: In the first episodes are about two or three scenes with stupid sexual jokes that are completely unncecessary and I don't like that. Fortunately, things like these don't ever appear again so I can pretty much ignore them.

[u]tl;dr lol[/u]
Buy it if...
you like visual novels or want to try them out,
you like whacky and crazy stories,
you like murder mystery stories

33919430.review:
A true masterpiece. I orignally completed Umineko from its original release, but oh boy, this remaster does not disappoint at all. It's hard to tell from looking at the promotion material, but this game - more technically a visual novel - is far, far more than what it seems. 

The story is fantastic; a stimulating murder mystery (or fantasy, that's up to you), one of the only few where you'll try to guess the outcome, to be only so very, very wrong, but for all the right reasons. This is a story where you must pay attention to all the small things, skimming over paragraphs of text will ruin the experence, but i promise you that if you follow patiently, you'll be well rewarded.

Visually, it's had a serious makeover and it does wonders. Backgrounds are vibrant and portray the story perfectly and the new character sprites are a wonderful addition.  There is the option to play with the original sprites but i won't blame you for using the remastered sprites. 

Audio design and soundtrack is fantastic, you MUST play with music on, 100% recommend using headphones. Music variety goes between from calming lullabies to tense requiems that'll leave you awake at night in a cold sweat.

Cannot wait for the Answer Arcs to be remastered, if you've ever wanted to try a visual novel, this is one for you.

33740381.review:
BEEATRIIIIIIIIIIICCCCCEEEEEEEEEEEEE!  Come back, I need you!  

The story is fun.  A little maddening, but it has a lot to say about your perceptions and how you react to especially the horrible things that happen in your life (more than just the murders).  The first arc is pretty straight forward, but after that it weaves in magic, with, especially at the end, the knowledge that all the deaths could happen without magic and that most of what you're seeing is twisted to make it look like it was done by magic.  That said, Battler is a bit of an idiot.  I kept wanting to yell at him to ask certain questions that he didn't get around to sometimes until arcs after the fact and then they were proven incorrect.  He also gives in, a lot, so all his proclaimations that he'll take it seriously this time, tend to fall a little flat.  

Also, Ange's story in the fourth arc was a little maddening and a little too depressing.  I liked the stuff about Maria, that was wonderful, but it took me a long time get into Ange.  

And then I was left hanging.  

This is a purely reading experience.  It has some pretty pictures, though they're repetitive and often don't show what the character is seeing and are just mood setting backdrops for the most part, though obviously some rooms are there.  The characters are nice to look at, though again, have limited poses they take to show their emotions.  And the characters they choose not to update in the last arc are really distracting, and I wish they'd done everybody, even if they were only for that arc because it was really weird.

The music is spot on, and the text is translated beautifully with hardly any mistakes that I could see and is a lot better than a lot fo heavy reading material I've picked up from Japan in a while. 

Though, as I said, this is a text reading story. You're not in control of what Battler says, all you can do is click and make the next line of text appear.  That said, it is a very enjoyable read :)

Now, WHERE"S THE CORE ARCS!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

33210504.review:
In the field of Chinese literature, there is a classic novel called Dream of the Red Chamber. This is a novel that is so vast in scope and so culturally influential, that it has an entire field of academic study dedicated to it, called Redology. Chinese literature scholars dedicate their entire careers to the critical analysis of this novel.

Umineko is the Red Chamber of our generation. 

As a work of art, Umineko has a certain quality that all literary masterpieces share: it tells a very specific story, but uses its specificity to express universal themes that all of us can relate to. If not for the mainstream bias against genre fiction and the visual novel medium, Umineko would be studied in postmodern literature classes, alongside the likes of One Hundred Years of Solitude. For me, Umineko has an even greater impact than many of the postmodern works I've experienced, because instead of focusing on experimental narrative techniques solely for experimental purposes, Umineko's unorthodox storytelling style exists for an important reason - to enable its exploration of underrepresented issues that resonate strongly with people like me, in a way that validates our perspectives. Ryukishi07's background as a social worker absolutely shows in his writing. 

Yes, for those of you who love mysteries, Umineko is a love letter to the genre; it will torture you with a mental challenge that you will never forget. For those of you who love gore and despair, Umineko serves up a delectable feast of horrors, with a roulette of delights that will never leave your palate bored or overwhelmed. For those of you who love witches and magic, you will fall in love with the golden witch and her fantastical feats, whose legends and stories will live on endlessly. 

But above all else - for those of you who have ever struggled with the terminal condition known as being human, this game is for you. 

Umineko is a brutally honest take on humanity and the role of storytelling in our lives, exploring its diverse cast of characters with love and clear-eyed objectivity in equal measure. And for some of us, Umineko resonates even more strongly, to the point that reading it may be excruciating. I will say nothing else on the matter - those of you who understand, will understand when you read it. 

All that said, there is one thing you should know. Umineko is designed with one rather thrilling peculiarity. And that is: you get out of Umineko exactly what you put into it. 

If you're not emotionally ready for it, or blast through it without much thought, Umineko may end up being just another story to you. But if you really take the time, pay attention, and above all, never stop thinking - then the witch will bestow countless gifts upon you, and welcome you to the Golden Land. This isn't the kind of lazy postmodern story that gives you nothing but a blank canvas full of random noise, that puts all the responsibility on the reader to create a meaningful story. This is an equal partnership of love. Umineko respects you and wants to meet you halfway - if you respect it in return and put in the effort to truly understand it. 

This is a question with an answer, a truth that you can reach. But it's a truth that's complex and multifaceted enough that you will be thinking about it for a thousand years to come. I know I certainly am. 

My understanding of Umineko is different from when I first read it, and I have no doubt that my understanding will continue to change in the years to come. I cried when I finished the final episode of the Answer Arc, even though I understood nothing. My actual journey began after that, when I started digesting the story and reading discussions about it online. I turned it over and over in my mind, licking and tasting and sucking on all its myriad flavours. And as I did, Umineko changed me - and is still continuing to change me. It was one of the major catalysts that helped me grow as a person, to be more mature, to have more empathy for the people around me. 

This is a story that I can see myself returning to in a year, in a decade, in a century, and coming away with different nuances and perspectives every single time. In that sense, I will forever be trapped in the catbox known as Rokkenjima. 

Won't you join me? 

This story is best paired with good friends, hot tea, and most crucially, the original sprites drawn by the author himself. Take your time with it. Savour it. We will be waiting for you, with love, in the Golden Land.

Мне, например, не нравятся черно-белые персонажи, как неисправимые паладины, так и отпетые негодяи, в жизни так не бывает, в каждом есть свои ангелы и демоны. В этом плане мне нравятся герои Достоевского, которые могут как одновременно восхищать, так и отвращать одновременно. Так-же не люблю нераскрытых персонажей, когда с интересом углубляешься в сюжет, и в конце выясняется, что про некоторых второстепенных героев вообще ничего сказать не сможешь, они настолько незаметны и неинтересны, будто они не личности, а какая-то мебель. Так вот, абсолютно каждый персонаж в этой игре продуман, как и индивидуальный набор положительных и отрицательных черт. Особенно хорошо получились дети Кинзно, даже в моменты, когда они настолько противны, что должны получить по лицу прилично, однако вместо этого у меня мурашки по коже идут, у меня дух захватывает, я вместо отвращения, восхищение испытываю, настолько такие ситуации реалистично показаны, что сам порую задумываешся, как бы ты поступил на их месте, правильно ли поступил я, если бы я бы был немного другим в жизни, смог бы я избежать эти отвратительные ситуации? Очень понравилась мне идея с гардеробом персонажей, да, он постоянно одиннаковый и не меняется когда жизнь кипит на острове, но это понятно, слуги есть слуги, им положено по статусу в униформе постоянно находиться, как и членам семьи во время семейных конференций. Однако, когда события происходят за пределами острова, все просто преображаются, прям так и хочется, что-бы некоторые герои ходили бы так почаще)
Что касается сюжета: не стану скрывать, мне очень нравится романтика, к моему счастью, ей посвященно очень много времени. Что радует в сюжете, так это то, что больше половины истории не вращается вокруг главного героя, хотя нет, я бы сказал по другому, здесь нету главного героя, нет нужды зацикливаться на гг, здесь есть множество героев, про которых рассказывает сюжет. Тут он четко поделен на две ветки: одна из них полностью посвящена семье Уширомия, тем, кто контактирует с ней, и тем, что вообще происходит на острове, эта ветка настолько продумана и длинна, что раскрывает основных героев со многих сторон, в каждой арке узнаешь что-то новое или интересное про основных персонажей. Ну и вторая ветка, которая посвященна мистике, как и первая ветка она точно по такому же принципу, но только раскрывает закулисных героев, таких, от которых очень сильно зависит главный спектакль. Они же и являются его творцами. В уминеках присутствуют очень много конфликтных ситуаций, ведь именно из них раскрываются определенные персонажи(исходя из их характера), а какие красочные кульминации в каждой арке. Прям так и хочется быстрей пропустить гору текста и поскорей добраться до судьбоносных моментов. Так-же хочется упомянуть про музыкальное сопровождение, скажу про него только то, что мне понравилось.

32192867.review:
[h1] Story & Writing [/h1]

Umineko is an experience that I will carry with me for the rest of my life for 2 reasons:

1. It has shown me the world from a new perspective.
2. I don't think I'll ever experience anything like Umineko again in my remaining lifetime.

It's extremely surreal, unique and stylish. You don't "read" it; you "experience" it, as it violently devours you, chews you up and spits you back out into its dark, magical and absurd world filled with batshit insane but impeccably executed murder mysteries, battles of wits and character drama. Umineko's sprawling story contains an unbelievable number of twists and turns that never stops giving, never relents, and never compromises. It always manages to top your expectations, to outdo itself in ways that are nigh impossible to predict..It's writing is rapturous, jubilant, energetic, profound, defiant, heartwarming, hearless, relentless, cruel, sadistic, romantic, psychotic, and edgy as fuck.

It's out of control. 

But you know what, it's edgy, but not depraved. It perfectly understands what it means to be "human," to love, to show compassion and kindness. Each and every single one of its characters are three-dimensional humans, and by the end of this sprawling story, you'll feel like you understand them even better than they understand themselves - such is the magic of Umineko's writing. The human heart lies at the very core of Umineko's story, and some mysteries are simply unsolvable unless one considers the "whydunnit," or the '"motive" side of the equation. Umineko constantly reminds the reader of this fact through it's most important mantra:

"Without love, it cannot be seen."

As for the more technical murder mystery side of things,
Umineko is a passionate love letter to the entire mystery genre.
It's a tribute to the great classical authors and thinkers who founded and nurtured the "mystery" label. 
It's a tribute to Agatha Christie and her impossible closed room mysteries 
it's a tribute to Knox, S.S Van Dine, and many many other great thinkers who crafted and perfected the rules for writing mysteries. 
It is an extremely compelling mystery that makes you think for yourself. It goes to extreme lengths to give you all the puzzle pieces, then explicitly tells you to connect the dots by yourself. 
And when all the answers [b]do[/b] fall into place, the only thing you can do is gasp. And that, my friend. is the mark of a good mystery.

You gotta read it to believe it. Really.

[h1] Soundtrack [/h1]
As for the soundtrack, what can I say that hasn't already been said before? I've played hundreds of games in my life, many of them with terrific soundtracks, but few has come close to Umineko's unreal soundtrack. From classy piano pieces to blood-pumping trance tracks, everything is here, and everything is amazing. During somber scenes, I  choke on my own tears. During climactic scenes, I want to grab a baseball bat, smash all the windows in my house, light the curtains on fire, and break my laptop in half. It doesn't get any more effective than that. Look up WorldendDominator, Miragecoordinator, or GoldenSlaughterer on Youtube. 


TLDR: 
Nothing I write can truly do this visual novel justice. Umineko is an experience of a lifetime, a feast for the senses, a banquet for the mind. It's shocking, oftentimes moving. It's surreal; it's stylish;  it's mind-bending, and it pushes the very boundaries of what [b]plain good[/b] writing can accomplish.

32186294.review:
The question arc in Umineko is one of the few series I would give a 10/10 for. The writing is superb and even the most experience murder myster novel fans will squrm at some of the gorey details. If you're worried the gore is only described in text there's no visiual of mutlated bodies or anything.

I love the occult aspect it's not something you see in mystery novels that take themselves seriously and focus on the detective aspect much.

Visiual novels are a great medium. They can do things books can't, of course neither is better than the other but give equally enjoyable experiences. With Visiual novels you find yourself, not working with the main character, but at your own pace to find your own answer to the closed room murders.

Now, more about the actual plot:

Umineko is a murder mystery about 18 rich people stuck on an island while murders are occuring. The main plot is between the main character, battler, trying to prove that the murders were done by humans, and not a witch with any supernatural abilities.

Most of the characters are as equally loveable and sympathetic as they are detestable.

About the author:
for someone who hasn't read anything by Ryukishi07 umineko might be a little confusing by episode 2. They way this series is written is each 'episode' gives a different view of the events. While things start out similar on the next episodes they're totally different, or give a totally different viewpoint of the murders. They're not like a sequel to each other more as they're a parallel telling of the story

Overall rating: 
I have already read the entire series. There's 8 'episodes' in total. While I give the quesiton arc, the first 4 episodes, a 10/10

The overall opinion on the ending is mixed by fans. While I enjoyed reading the final 'episode'  I found myself disastified with the ending.

For the entire series I would give it a 9/10 for its...odd ending.

31479608.review:
Umineko no Naku Koro ni is a tale where the lines of reality and fantasy blur together. It invites you to discover the reason behind the murders as well as "who did it". But, in all my years having reread this timeless tale, I've come to realize it isn't entirely about the mystery. It's a tale of friendship and worlds that everyone is capable of creating for themselves. This novel is one of the greatest works of fiction -albeit, frustrating if you're trying to solve every mystery- and Ryukishi is simply not credited enough for the amazing experience you will get out of this novel.

Who is Beatrice? What really occurred on Rokkenjima? What is the meaning behind this?

I promise you, by the end of this tale you will view life a little differently. This is a tale for the dreamers, the detectives, the witches, and the humans. It's a tale for anyone and everyone, but it takes a lot of thought and possibly rereading to understand what it means fully. (Once the Core Arcs are on Steam, that definitely adds more layers of worlds to this tale, and helps with understanding it all.) It is a tale that is meant to be enjoyed slowly, thought over for endless nights, and read over again simply to be welcomed back to the inviting and spectacular cast we've all come to know and love.

If you try anything new, please make in Umineko. You will not regret it.

31393306.review:
Umineko is a kinetic visual novel that consists of four question arcs.  For those familiar with the Higurashi When They Cry series, question arcs present a mystery scenario where the same event occurs but with little differences, such as different persepectives and different minor events.  It is up to the reader to figure out how to solve those mysteries although the question arcs don't give the reader the answer right away.  The answers are reserved for the answer or core arcs.  Thus, Umineko has only the question arcs for now although hopefully, the core arcs will come on Steam sometime in the future.

In Umineko, the reader mostly takes on various roles (the first arc is from Battler Ushiromiya's perspective, the second is a more third person perspective, the third has Eva Ushiromiya's and Beatrice's perspectives, and the fourth has Ange Ushiromiya's and Battler's perspectives) and we're introduced to the island of Rokkenjima.  The first question arc sets up the scenario nicely where we're introduced to Battler and his family members who plan to go to the island for the annual family conference that takes place on October 4, 1986.  The siblings, including Battler's dad, plan to argue over their father's inheritance, as it is reported that he doesn't have much time to live.  However, after the family members arrive on the island and get settled in, a series of horrific murders take place and these murders are so bizarre that there is the question of whether magic exists.  I won't say anything more than that, for spoiler purposes, but that's basically how most of the question arcs proceed.  Starting from the second to fourth arcs, they're played as a game between Battler and the golden, endless witch Beatrice in the "meta-world" where Battler argues that the murders can happen because of humans while Beatrice argues that witches and magic exist.  So that's how the stories in the Umineko question arcs proceed.

As to my opinion, I really enjoyed Umineko.  As much as I like the Higurashi When They Cry series, I'm having difficulty deciding whether I like Higurashi or Umineko more.  It's just that good.  The writing is excellent and I love the whole premise of treating things as a game.  Also, I am a fan of mysteries so I got invested in trying to figure out how certain events could have happened.  Especially, I like the fourth arc because we get to see Ange's perspective, as she was not on Rokkenjima at the time, so she investigates as to what happened.  Also, I like Ange's personal story, as I could relate to it a lot.  Of course, the end of the fourth arc leaves off on a cliffhanger and I really want the core arcs to come on Steam so I can continue the Umineko story.  In addition, I like the additional features that get unlocked after you finish an episode, like the tea parties, ???, and tips that give additional information to help solve the mysteries.  I wish that there would have been additional features unlocked, like getting to replay certain chapters.  That feature is present in the Higurashi series but not in Umineko.

Overall, I highly enjoyed Umineko and although it did take me a while to finish it, it was definitely time worth spent.  I'd recommend this to anyone who likes visual novels and doesn't mind reading through a kinetic novel.  Even though there aren't any choices, just reading it got me engrossed and I want to find out what happens next.  I want to find out how the next game board will be set up.  Of course, Higurashi fans will enjoy Umineko as well although it isn't necessary to have played any of the Higurashi games.  There are a couple of Higurashi references and you will probably figure out who one of the Umineko characters is tied to in Higurashi but other than that, you can entirely skip over playing Higurashi.  So if you're wanting to read an enjoyable mystery that'll leave you guessing (and if you don't mind the horror aspects, as I should warn that there are some), I'd highly recommend picking up Umineko.  ^^

31246860.review:
海猫鸣泣之时这部作品已经出现了电子小说、漫画、动画三种诉说故事的体裁，而且都有汉化。先来谈谈动画版的《海猫》，10分制下，原作小说和漫画我给10分，而动画只能给6.6分。原因在于被动画监督今千秋给毁了，首先，动画没有解谜篇《散》差评，推理悬疑作的观众看不到解谜可是很失望的。补完原作我才发现海猫动画改得真烂啊，结尾都给删减成啥样了，导致销量暴死，至今也没有《散》的动画版。因为不尊重原作乱删减剧情，今千秋监督被原作党戏称为“金铅球”。 

接下来说说海猫鸣泣之时的漫画，漫画版比动画版的水平不知道高到哪里去了。漫画完全尊重原著，如果你想了解海猫的故事，又不想看这么坑的动画和读这么长时间的电子小说，漫画是最好的媒介和选择（可通过网易漫画APP观看）。相比原作，8部漫画里我最喜欢的还是EP7水野英多老师的画风，简直太赞！8部漫画的分镜都可圈可点，感染力极强，一边听海猫的OST一边看漫画是非常愉快的体验。相比原作电子小说，漫画有以下优点： 
1、解答原作一些没揭示的密室手法和诡计，为海猫这部作品画上了圆满的句号。 
2、分镜带来的冲击力和画面感是小说比不了的。 
3、虽然还是有魔法大战，但不会让读者有种被魔法or推理愚弄的感觉，反而觉得很燃。 
4、EP8中的“魔女的自白”部分使贝阿朵莉切的人物形象更加真实饱满，同时使整个故事的前因后果更加清晰。
感谢有漫画这样的平台能让故事重新演绎并且填坑，弥补了原作的小缺点。同时以上优点使海猫成为了“完全之作”，也从真正意义上比肩甚至超越了寒蝉鸣泣之时。 

接下来到原作电子小说的评价，动画化的失败使得海猫终究只是小众冷门作。这里提一下infinity系列的第三作“Remember11”，海猫和Remember11一样，两作独特的内容使其成为ACG推理悬疑界的“异端”：Remember11是没有给出谜题的答案，需要读者自己进行推理解答，导致诸多差评；而海猫则是把幻想和奇幻剧的元素融入本应严谨的推理悬疑作品中，虽然结尾处核心诡计已经真相大白，然而出题篇的密室诡计和手法并未完全揭示，同样需要读者自行推理（这点已在漫画版里得到补全，所以我还是推荐看漫画）。而在故事中出现的魔法大战，可能也会让部分读者有着被魔法or推理愚弄的感觉。因此网上有这样的问题：“Remember11和海猫哪个更坑人？”。在豆瓣和bangumi评分中，两者皆是毁誉参半两极分化。此外，《散》篇中龙骑士一边抛出诺克斯十诫和范达因二十则来证明此作十分“本格”，一方面又不断违反十诫和二十则，这看起来就感觉有些好笑了。（十诫和二十则这种陈腐的教条早就该埋进土里了，且不说新本格时代的作品瑰宝，就连黄金时代的推理小说家也不断打破这些教条，这才有了推理小说的各路流派和发扬光大。）以上均为该作明显的缺点部分。不过，当你读完全篇的文本之后，你会发现这些谜团都是有“目的”的，甚至作者不给出解答也是一种“目的”，这点在Remember11也同理。 

也有人说，海猫是反推理的推理作品，对于这种说法我十分同意。除了在推理悬疑作品中加入奇幻元素，还有一个很重要的理由是这个故事的本身也是非常“唯心”的。薛定谔的猫/箱子里的猫是支撑本作世界观的重要理论，奇幻or推理，魔法or真实，带上了人为的主观色彩。因此相比其他推理作品，海猫非常的“唯心主义”。虽然毁誉参半，但Remember11和海猫这两部作品对于我来说都属于“誉”的那一方。海猫鸣泣之时是一部被低估的作品，相比寒蝉我个人更爱海猫。虽然有缺点，我依然愿意给这两部作品高分。 

如果有读者没有看完全部的EP8的真结局和里茶会（打出这里的条件是，需要在最后的分支选项里选“魔法”这个选项），那你是没有资格点评海猫的。之所以会这样说，这是因为我当时在看到EP7和EP8的时候真心觉得龙骑士在故弄玄虚，混乱的魔法和讲不清的诡计感觉也是在戏弄玩家和读者（关于龙骑士“愚弄”读者的前因后果，推荐阅读知乎的一篇文章：谁改变了龙骑士07？——《海猫鸣泣之时》创作秘话 https://zhuanlan.zhihu.com/p/23595803 ）。不过当我看到游戏的真结局同时补完漫画的EP7-8的时候，心中对这部作品的评价完全改变了。从《散》篇开始，故事其实就在不断暗示核心诡计了。通读全篇你会发现从EP5-EP8有大量细节在暗示核心诡计，从EP1-EP8几条明线暗线也前后呼应，着实为龙骑士07埋伏笔的功力点赞！EP7-8基本上填了之前挖的大部分坑。EP8的里茶会揭示了本作最大的核心诡计，虽然不能称得上惊为天人但也是十分震撼了，然而最打动我的并非诡计，而是故事和人物本身（这点在漫画里也表现得同样出色）。结尾的对话配上神曲“白梦之茧”带给读者的是让人泪目和震撼的感动，不论是悲伤还是希望，海猫的主题都值得人回味和深思。此外，感谢海猫的背景音乐创作者带来如此多治愈人心的音乐，尤其是M.Graveyard大神！你们的音乐让这部作品有了更大的魅力！ 

最后用一段话来总结吧：我讨厌这个故事，因为故事的真相充满悲伤。而我又喜欢这个故事，就如同该作的神曲“Hope”一样，它充满着希望。结尾是Bad End还是Happy End已经不重要，海猫带给读者的是无尽的感动和治愈。这个故事，献给最爱的魔女贝阿朵莉切，“没有爱，就看不见”。神作。

PS：最后的最后，虽然不想把这段话发在评测区，但由于这种事情不止一次发生，所以还是要声明如下：不论你以何种方式转载（文字、截图等），请注明原作者以及原文链接，否则视为侵权，作为原作者看见这样的事情真的不开心啊。[spoiler]话说海猫的安利文就这么少吗？就盯上我一个？[/spoiler]还希望诸位专栏与公众号多多注意。

30228039.review: Umineko is possibly the best mystery novel I have ever read and even if you don't like visual novels and just enjoy reading a good book I can confidently say that you would still enjoy Umineko, it has an amazing story, a large cast of detailed and relatable characters, and a godly soundtrack, I think that generally, murder mysteries should try to stay as realistic as possible but Umineko is one of the few exceptions, the only cons are that it is quite slow (so if you are impatient then this visual novel might not be for you), and the next problem I have with it is that the new art isn't that great but that can be fixed by installing a patch which includes the all of the ps3 sprites, backgrounds, and voice acting, this next thing is not really a con but some people might not like that it is a sound novel so it has no interactivity but that is ok with me because I enjoy reading books quite often so I am fine with no real interactivity, so in conclusion Umineko is my most confident 10/10 I have ever given to a Visual novel or to just about anything.

Without a doubt in my mind the greatest story I have ever read/seen/played/any other word for absorbing media. 07th Expansion not only created a mystery novel that throws the genre on its head; it introduced a wide variety of fleshed-out characters that all have unique contributions to the story, created a strong narrative with these characters in between all the mysteries, taught me new points of view in life, made me audibly laugh on a few occasions, spooked me without jumpscares, made me cry, and had an incredible soundtrack to boot. Again, the soundtrack is something to be admired and is the enhancing agent for this whole story, Turning a happy scene into a brief respite from the story's horrors, a turning-point into a heart-throbbing catharsis, a debate into a tantalizing final struggle between rivals, the list goes on. 

Umineko does have its shortcomings however so i'll stop praising it for just a moment to address these. Despite the strength of the soundtrack, the novel’s sound effects are average at best, with some of them becoming quite overused due to their lack of variety. The pacing of the story is a little wonky. So if you aren't the type of person who is fine with 6 hours of character back-stories and conversations that allude to the themes of the story, Umineko will be aggravating for you. 

This product's main weakness however, is the Steam version of this game being mostly inferior to the PS3 version, this is due to a lack of voice acting and the Steam version's lower quality sprites and backgrounds. Though, this problem can be remedied with a 3GB download after a quick google search "Umineko PS3 Patch".


[b] A quick review of the strong/weak points [/b]
+Great story with many facets
+One of the greatest soundtracks ever made
+Relatable and round characters 
+The mystery is both enthralling and exciting to try and solve
+This story departs from many visual novel tropes 

-The sound effects could be improved 
-The slow pacing may dissuade people from reading it
-A 3rd party download is needed to get an optimal experience
-Battler says some creepy shit sometimes

I will end this by saying if you had the patience to read this review in full and have even a slight interest in the mystery genre, get this novel. Also I recommend getting a set colored pens and a notebook.

A side note: Umineko Question Arc is the first 4 episodes of an 8 episode series. I know very little about the Answer Arc as of now, so my review is only talking about the Question Arc.

Thank you for reading this review and I hope it helped you make a decision.

29589006.review:
this review is spoiler-free.

this game contains the first half of Umineko No Naku Koro Ni, and my playtime doesn't reflect the total time I spent on this series at all - should be closer to 150-200 hours of reading. Umineko isn't a game in the traditional sense, but a sound novel, which means it's mostly not interactive and should be viewed as a book with art, voice acting* and a soundtrack.

the premise of the novel resembles that of a classic murder mystery, but without going into more detail, it evolves into a story that involves so much more - even if you're put off by the initial premise, i'd still recommend giving the book a go. it made a huge impression on me and is an experience i'm likely to never forget.

the list of positives about the novel is too huge for me to write up, but the biggest thing I fell in love with was the depth - it's a story that you can easily dive into if you have the time, and it's truly immersive and well written from the intricate plot to the fleshed out character cast. the soundtrack is also insanely good and I still find myself listening to many of the tracks. 

as for what might put some readers off - this game/book requires your full attention when progressing through the story, and really urges the reader to think. it works on "show, don't tell" principles, so some readers might be left thinking "wait what?" at some parts of the story. it's extremely hard to ever predict what happens next, and some parts might be hard to understand without further research.

Umineko as a whole is a very compelling read and deserves a 10/10 rating from me - it might be a bit slow at the start for some, but the payoff that comes with finishing the series feels extremely rewarding. it's been a month or two since I finished my initial readthrough, and I still find myself thinking about the universe and its characters. for me, that's what really makes a great book/game/whatever you want to call it - lasting appeal and impact.

*voice acting isn't included in the steam patch, but the ps3 patch of the game includes (arguably) better sprites and voice acting. the voice acting is actually really good and adds a lot to the personalities of the characters, so I'd highly recommend getting it.

29295215.review:
After finishing the Higurashi novels recently, I decided invest time into the successor series, Umineko, to fill the void that Higurashi had left behind.

I wasn't disappointed.

But to be honest, I didn't really expect much at first. In fact, I felt the intro sequence was quite stiff and difficult to adjust to. However, what followed was a mind-bending, unsettling, yet moving tale that left my jaw wide open. Umineko goes beyond the normal definition of "mystery." It challenges the reader to consider a wide range of perspectives. It breathes life into the characters, making it difficult for one not to sympathize with those who may be considered evil or antagonistic. The soundtrack is lovely and fitting, contributing greatly to the overall atmosphere of the novel. I would reccomend reading Umineko after reading Higurashi. It's not required, but it grants one a unique perspective to approach Umineko initially. Also, Umineko contains many references to characters and events from Higurashi.

Overall, Umineko is a fantastic novel and I reccomend it to anyone who's willing to invest their time into it.

29130281.review:
(Ignore my (EDIT: relatively) low playtime here. I own a non-Steam version from a few years back, and have poured countless hours into that.)

Umineko, out of all the stories I've read, is probably my single favourite work of fiction. I don't think anything's moved me quite as much as Umineko has, before or since I first read it. It's changed the way I think and approach others, definitely for the better.

The basic premise isn't the most original thing in the world - it's very apparent that it was inspired by And Then There Were None, and it doesn't shy away from other references to its inspirations - but the attention to detail put into how it's done is superb.

The soundtrack is absolutely phenomenal - while I wouldn't go listening to some of the songs from it on my own, I wouldn't skip through any of them if they were to start playing. The game's use of the soundtrack is also masterful - Ryukishi07 is very skilled at building an atmosphere, through writing and use of music together.

The cast of characters is quite sizeable (starting at 18, and it only grows from there!), but all of the key characters are wonderfully fleshed out, and most of them are explored in-depth. Some of them aren't explored as much, which is unfortunate, but it's still clear that a lot of thought and love went into every single character. They all feel like real human beings, with their own strengths and flaws, their own shining, heroic qualities, and their own base, selfish, sometimes even cruel ones.

Umineko is definitely not for everyone - it's quite long and very dense, and it can get difficult to follow exactly what's important and what isn't later on. Having said that, I would very highly recommend it - it's a masterfully written work. While it's got its flaws (the writing is slightly clumsy at times, and the pacing can be quite messy), the amount of thought, love, and care that went into writing it shines through brightly. $30 might sound a bit steep (for those of us in Canada at least, hooray exchange rates!), but it's more than a fair price for the amount of content you get.

Definitely looking forward to the arrival of Chiru and Golden Fantasia.

EDIT Jan 27th: I kinda wish I'd remembered this earlier - the PS3 version patch. Opinions on the Steam sprites aside, the PS3 patch also includes redrawn backgrounds and voice-overs. Personally, I'd consider the voicework essential to the experience - Sayaka Ohara's performance as Beatrice is phenomenal, and there are some important details in the dialogue that simply don't translate to English at all. I would strongly recommend the PS3 patch for that alone.

27751302.review:
Umineko is my favorite visual novel, but even I am somewhat hesitant to recommend it without reservation. Thing is, Umineko is an odd beast, and even assigning it a genre would be grossly misleading. At its heart, however, it is a Deconstruction, of the Mystery genre, the Fantasy genre and of half a dozen other things whenever it feels like it.

The plot starts slow and simple: A family reunion on an isolated island, hints of magic and the occult and a perfect setup for a Murder Mystery that directly references Agatha Christie's And Then There Were None. I will admit, a huge chunk of the first Episode is painfully slow, but it also perfectly sets up the pieces and crafted a perfect stage for confusion and uncertainty in both characters and readers. It is a prologue around 10 hours long and at times it feels a bit excessive, but once it gets going the air of paranoia and distrust seeps into the cast perfectly. Once the setup is out of the way however, Umineko descends to bizarre and wonderful places with multiple stories going at once and characters openly questioning the genre of the work they are in. It is at times a real cluster and way too obtuse for its own good, but these are, in my opinion, small sacrifices for a visual novel that is perhaps unmatched in how strange and ambitious it is. Also, note that this is only the first half of Umineko so not every question will be answered. But do no wait for the solution to be revealed because the cat box can only stay close for so long. Enjoy dissecting the story and characters and come to your own answer before the box is opened.

The cast is also a highlight. If you are familiar with visual novels, you can tell right away that Umineko is not a typical one. The cast is comprised of mostly adults and avoids any typical archetype of the genre. Many characters start off nice and simple but when the chips are down they show a side to them that is both surprising and understandable in retrospect. Some episodes focus on a few specific characters, giving strong insight into their psychology and making them increasingly morally questionable and yet undeniably sympathetic. It is a testament to the writing that not one character can be singled out as the one who is there to be the moral compass or the villain. They are people first and foremost and their actions and personality are always understandable given the hand they were dealt.

As for the visuals, you know what you are getting into. The game comes with new sprites (and a few CGs) as well as the original ones. The Steam graphics are somewhat grittier and more realistic (occasionally absurd breasts aside) while the originals have a unique charm to them and are also amazingly expressive. Unfortunately the PS3 sprites, which is the cleanest and also most anime-y of the lot, isn't included in the package. I personally find the new sprites to be a good alternative to the original, but as someone who really prefers the PS3 sprites, they are both rather wanting. You can form your opinion by looking at the screenshots, but I will say that I liked them a lot more than I thought I would once I'm in the actual game. It is also a real shame that the voice acting, which was exclusive to the PS3 version, was removed because the actors really brought their A game. I do not want to talk about things that are not in this release but I will wholeheartedly recommend grabbing the patch that brings back the voice acting and the PS3 sprites because the voices are wonderful. The soundtrack, on the other hand, is as perfect as ever, and that is all that needs to be said.

If you have not played Umineko, chances are you are here because you played/watched Higurashi or, worse, watched the anime adaptation. If this is the case I urge you to discard any presumption on what this visual novel is. There are similarities to Higurashi here, and the anime technically follows the same plot line as Episode 1-4, but neither of them are indicative of what Umineko is. I do realize that this review did very little to illuminate on what Umineko is actually about, but trust me when I say that explaining that would be as counterproductive as it would be impossible. If you like the format of Visual Novels, if you like Murder Mystery, if you like character study and if you like something that is just plain strange, give Umineko a shot. I cannot say you won't regret it, but you'll certainly see something you haven't seen before.

Note: Do note that I finished the game once already, but not the steam version. Do know that my playtime is not at all indicative of the actual playtime of the game. 10 hours will probably get you half way through Episode 1 and all four Episodes will likely take you over 50 hours, so if you are worried about value in term of playtime, put that thought to rest. Umineko is absurdly long so you got that covered.

27285831.review:
Umineko no Naku Koro Ni ("When The Seagulls Cry") is the second sound novel by Ryukishi07, after the similarly named Higurashi no Naku Koro Ni ("When The Cicadas Cry"). The two do not share a plot and can be experienced separately, but rarely some characters from Umineko mention minor plot points or concepts from Higurashi. It is inspired by Agatha Christie's And Then There Were None and S. S. Van Dine's The Greene Murder Case, sharing themes such as members of a same family being under threat, and people being stuck on an island with a murderer on the loose.
Unlike most visual novels that get to the West, there is little to no interactivity to Umineko in general and none at all in  Episodes 1 through 4 here, which make up the first half of the complete novel. There is no gameplay, no choice-making, no dating system. Just reading and listening to the soundtrack (which, by the way, is awesome). It is, effectively, no more than a novel with music, background art and character sprites. But what a novel it is.

Umineko's plot starts out kinda normal: you're being asked to solve murders, as in any other piece of detective fiction. But as you keep reading (= Episode 2 and on), stranger things start to come up. If you aren't deterred by these oddities and keep on reasoning instead of going "screw that", Umineko rewards you greatly.
If you are expecting a traditional murder mystery, this is not it. If you are intrigued by having to fight tooth and claw for your clues against unreliable narrators and Jedi truths which are technically true, but ambiguous and potentially misleading, Umineko is for you. While it isn't straightforward by any means, I feel it is never unfair. Its storytelling has hidden rules and it follows them closely, even if it's not immediately apparent: once you do understand the rules, you start regaining ground and fighting on equal footing. It never insults your intelligence by going "if you didn't figure it out yourself here it is".

Don't be misled by the relatively low hour count and achievement count I have for Umineko on Steam. I've already read through all eight Episodes on the original PC version, but I simply had to pick up this one for the updated translation and... Well, general love I have for Umineko. So if what I've mentioned so far has appealed to your curiosity, pick it up and read it! It's worth it.

27186898.review:
Mysterious, romantic, magic, fascinating, mindscrewing, absurd, philosophical, deceiving. There are thousands of reasons why Umineko is the most unparalleled masterpiece in the history of visual novels. Umineko No Naku Koro Ni (When the Seagulls Cry) is a eight episode visual novel written by the author of the Higurashi When They Cry series, but the overall game is on a whole new scale when likened to its spiritual predecessor.
It all begins during the time frame of october 4 and 5, on a small, secluded island named Rokkenjima:
The plot begins with a flat slice of life-ish premise that could lead the readers to regard the VN as a simple-minded story: enter the entire Ushiromiya household, one of the wealthiest families in the world which struck it rich thanks to the head of the household, Kinzo, whose means of achieving his vast fortune remains shrouded in mystery. In view of the death of his aged grandparents, Battler Ushiromiya, the missing member of the household who has been living away from his parents for six years, decides to attend the gathering. Subsequently, upon coming together for the presumed last family meeting, each member is introduced, however, the situation takes a turn for the worse when a fierce typhoon preys upon Rokkenjima, the phenomenon marks the death sentence of the whole household, as one by one each member becomes the victim of a bizarre and brutal chain of murders attributed to a mysterious serial killer which later is revealed to be the Golden Witch Beatrice, Kinzo's secret lover and owner of the gold stack of the island. Battler refuses to believe in magic in spite of the given evidence, and concludes that the culprit of the accident is merely the 19th and hidden human on Rokkenjima, until the ultimate proof is shown to his eyes: The Golden Witch in flesh and blood. This insane happening paves the road for a magnum opus in which occult, braintwisters, love, action, tenderness and sympathy intermingle with each other to give life to a true work of art that remains unsurpassed even a decade after its initial release. Pretty much everything in the VN is executed flawlessly, ranging from the ample assortment of nearly one hundred BGMs to the writing, the art, and the multiple narratives throughout the game. The author succeeds in providing an accurate portrayal of the psychological situation of every character in the game, as such, providing remarkable backstories for the entire cast. The writing is one of a kind and absolutely phenomenal, likewise the author manages to strike right into the hearth of the readers, making it one of the most stunning works of the century.
The first half may sound slightly slow-paced, but I can assure the readers are in for one hell of a ride, Umineko No Naku Koro Ni is the ultimate life-changing experience that simply cannot be missed if you're into visual novels or complex, intriguing and thoughtful stories. I have gone through the 100 hours of the game twice, and not once have I been unsatisfied; Umineko is a VN that can easily be replayed over and over at any age. The game is best played with the PS3 sprites patch and the voice acting which makes for a whole new experience;
at the end of the day, I wholeheartedly am willing to replay it once again when Manga Gamer will release the Answer Arcs. Umineko simply cannot be explained with words alone, moreover it's incredibly hard to spoil to someone because of its sophisticated depth, no other VN can be compared to Umineko because no VN is as unique and breathtaking as Ryukishi's.

26874677.review:
(I've completed this game using the Witch Hunt translation, so everything I say will be coming from that)

Umineko is a visual novel released between 2007 and late 2010 (with these episodes, the Question Arcs, being released in 2007 and 2008). It is a murder mystey/fantasy novel packed with tons of content to keep you on your toes at all times... for the most part.

The story itself is probably one of the best things I've ever read, including all visual novels, regular novels, fiction/non-fiction, etc.. In short, it involves a family going to an island that is only inhabited by the family head and a some other family members. They go there, and they recieve a letter from a mysterious entity calling themselves "Beatrice", saying they must find the gold hidden on the island, or she will be forced to recieve "interest" from them. From then on, strange things happen, and people start questioning their trust for each other, yada yada other murder mystery things.

While the story is amazing, it DOES drag for a bit for the first 4-6 hours, basically the entire first in game day in the first episode. After that though, the story hooks you in and refuses to let go until you've ended up binging the entire episode, and it only leaves you craving more.

One thing I especially love about Umineko is how, even though it has LOTS of them (There are at least 18[!] of them introduced just in the first day of the first episode alone, and there are MANY more introduced later), it uses all its characters efficiently. You're never left feeling some characters are under utilized or under developed. Even though some characters definitely get more development than others (but really, in a cast of so many characters, can you blame them?), even the most under developed character still feels complete.

All in all, Umineko is probably one of the most visual novels, let alone novels, in the past decade. I would 100% recommend it to anyone looking for a good read.

9.5/10
